body: Dozens of New York City supermarkets are still locking in their janitors at night, even after neighborhood and labor groups began urging government officials to crack down on the practice six months ago, janitors and community leaders say. Five janitors said in interviews that supermarkets in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx still locked them in,
title: Janitors Say Supermarkets Are Still Locking Them In

body: After several false starts, state and city officials are set to sign off on a new, final master plan for the Downtown Brooklyn waterfront that would include playing fields, a marina, stores and a new residential and commercial hub at the foot of Atlantic Avenue. The plan for the 1.3-mile shoreline park from Dumbo to Cobble Hill is a crucial step
title: Brooklyn Waterfront Park Inches Closer

author: Helene Stapinski is the author of two memoirs, ''Five-Finger Discount'' and ''Baby Plays Around.''
body: OURS was a typical New York apartment building: parents hurrying to work, nannies pushing strollers, stay-at-home mothers sidestepping the porter mopping the hall as they rushed out to fetch their children from school. It was a building like any other, one in which people rarely had much time to stop and talk. Until Norton came along. Norton was a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; A Condo's Best Friend

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: FOR Sara Antunovich and her boyfriend, Orion Montoya, moving from Chicago to New York was an experience so arduous that, had they known, they would have done everything differently. Maybe it was bad luck or bad planning, too much optimism or too little skepticism. They lowered their expectations and raised their price range. They wiped out their
title: THE HUNT; A Fresh Start Loses Its Freshness

body: Attractions Museums AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. On view through Jan. 10, the Origami Holiday Tree, with hundreds of colorful paper ornaments and volunteers teaching origami daily, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Through May 30, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' a walk-in display of
title: Spare Times

body: TEN years ago, Gregory Hedberg, the director of European art at the Hirschl & Adler Galleries in Manhattan, and his wife, Margaret, who runs the International Debutante Ball, bought a town house on the Upper East Side. Last year, they promised not to alter its facade. That promise resulted in a $563,000 income tax deduction, which Mr. Hedberg said
title: Rushing for Tax Breaks on Historic Houses

body: Attractions Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE 36-01 35th Avenue, at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. One of the largest collections of moving-image artifacts. Through Jan. 23, ''Tim Burton Drawings,'' an exhibition of more than 24 drawings, watercolors and sketches related to his films. Screenings this weekend: Tonight at 7:30 and
title: Spare Times

author: E-mail: society@nytimes.com -- Information: (212) 556-1141
body: Recalling a Landmark THURSDAY -- Danny Glover will be the master of ceremonies at a dinner at the Hilton New York to benefit the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund. Three members of the legal team that won the landmark school desegregation case Brown v. Board of Education will be honored. Cocktails at 6:30 and dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $500,
title: BENEFITS

body: ELI'S VINEGAR FACTORY, the market at 431 East 91st Street, is to reopen tomorrow, following a fire on Sunday night that damaged an adjacent space housing its pastry kitchens and rooftop greenhouses. ELI ZABAR, the owner, said he plans to rebuild. In the meantime he will use kitchens in other buildings he owns around New York City to bake his cakes
title: FOOD STUFF; Off the Menu

body: BIBLO--Frances D. Widow of the late Jack Biblo, co-owner of Biblo and Tannen Booksellers of 4th Avenue in Manhattan, on Friday, October 8, 2004, at her home in Brooklyn Heights after a short illness. She was 93. A retired NYC school teacher, prior to her death she was active as the proprietor of Biblo Books, an antiquarian bookstore in Brooklyn
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BIBLO, FRANCES D.

body: BUZZY O'KEEFE'S foie gras vendors thought he was nuts when he opened the tony River Cafe in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1977. ''Everybody in New York said I was out of my mind, that nobody would come to Brooklyn,'' he said. ''When I first opened up,'' he added, ''they were afraid.'' That was then. Now that once-grotty waterfront parcel is
title: LIVING IN/Brooklyn Heights; A Graceful Bastion in a Swirling Borough

body: BESHEER--Hasna Azizi, 95, Papal Lady. Wife of the late Simon. Cherished daughter of the late Boutros and Salma Dahdah Azizi. Devoted mother of Salma Besheer Vahdat and the late Sahid. Loving sister of Eva, Dumit and Diana. Proud grandmother of six and great grandmother of eight. Reposing at Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, Thursday,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BESHEER, HASNA AZIZI

body: WHEN Connecticut cities were at a low ebb in the early 1980's, officials from Norwalk visited Portland, Me., where a revival was under way, generated by the city's historic waterfront. Nineteenth-century brick maritime and industrial buildings were transformed into art galleries, studios, shops, restaurants, offices and apartments. Real estate was
title: LIVING IN/South Norwalk, Conn.; A Revival, and Houses That Won't Quit

body: It is hard to say just what has gotten into people at the Van Voorhees Park tennis courts in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Maybe there is road rage spillover from the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, a few steps to the east, or maybe the broad-shouldered specter of the container ports a few steps west is giving players a little extra swagger. Whatever the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; Wearing Boxing Gloves With Those Tennis Whites

author: Suzy Hansen is an editor at The New York Observer.
body: MY OLD MAN By Amy Sohn. 320 pp. Simon & Schuster. $23. Amy Sohn has the whole sex-writer business down cold. She was a sex columnist for The New York Press, is now a sex columnist for New York magazine, and her first novel, ''Run Catch Kiss,'' about a sex columnist named Ariel Steiner, featured lots of awkward and hot s-e-x. But ''Run Catch Kiss,''
title: From Moses to the Marquis de Sade

body: Diane and Joseph DiMeo opened their storefront cooking school, the Neighborhood Kitchen, in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, a couple of weeks ago with a focus on home cooking, said Ms. DiMeo, who was a cook at Patois in Brooklyn. The classroom, a former diner at 231 Court Street (Warren Street), is equipped with stainless steel counters and professional
title: FOOD STUFF; A Back-to-School Offer for Home Cooks

body: HSU--Susan. Died September 11, 2004. Founder of popular Su Su Yum Yum restaurant in Brooklyn Heights. Services at Cobble Hill Chapel, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, New York, 718-875-1640 or 718-522-3981. Viewing 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM Tuesday. Memorial service Wednesday, September 15, 12 noon. Burial service to follow at Kensico Cemetery, 3 PM.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HSU, SUSAN

body: The legislation passed 19 months ago, but few people, it seems, have taken note that chatting on your cellphone in a New York City movie theater is now illegal. Three teenagers who had left the United Artists Court Street Stadium 12 theater in Brooklyn were unaware of the law last week when asked about it by a reporter. One of them offered a
title: Despite Cellphone Ban in Theaters, Dialing Continues

body: IT is curiosity, above all, that puts this baby, at least provisionally, on the list of the fall's must-sees. What could a show so bluntly and broadly titled as ''Brooklyn, the Musical'' possibly deliver? A choral dirge in which sad legions take to the stage to lament the flight of the Dodgers, perhaps. A shaggy bunch of Williamsburg neo-bohemians
title: THE NEW SEASON/THEATER; A Girl Named Brooklyn

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: WORKING from home went well for Michael Friedman as long as he worked alone. Then, as his one-man public relations business grew, he seriously considered hiring an employee. But he knew it would be awkward having someone come to work in his apartment in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn -- a railroad flat where his small office opened right into the
title: THE HUNT; Outgrowing The Home Office

body: New York City's ambitious effort to give physical exams and blood tests to more than 2,000 people has run into unexpected trouble getting residents to participate, especially in affluent areas. City health officials hope to use the results to compile a detailed portrait of the city's health, but that means getting a representative sampling from
title: For Health Survey, Many Offer More Excuses Than Details

body: To the Editor: I related to ''Toughest Hazard? Getting to the First Tee,'' by William McDonald (Coping column, Aug. 22). I am a New York tour guide and love telling out-of-town golfers how I once got to a course. I walked (with my bag, of course) from my apartment in Brooklyn to the subway about 15 minutes away and took it to Lower Manhattan, where
title: Long Way to the Green

body: IT'S hard to miss the eight or nine dogs in Claire Angelica's apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. They yap and jump and are in danger of being stepped on. But the cats emerge Cheshire-like from nowhere: a black one slides off a kitchen cabinet, a white one materializes near the sink, and a fluffy calico stirs behind the coffee maker. The phenomenon
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; A Rescuer Of Animals Draws Some Yelps

body: With condominium prices soaring, Mario Procida, a seasoned developer from the Bronx, decided that the building he was putting up at 53 Boerum Place in the first of a swath of residential buildings going up on the edge of downtown Brooklyn could make it as a condominium, rather than a rental. So he put in the usual condo upgrades: a 24-hour
title: POSTINGS; Where High-Tech And Luxury Meet

body: ON Jan. 22, 1856, a group of Jewish men from Brooklyn gathered at the Myrtle Avenue home of a Mr. Ross to discuss their ''earnest desire'' to found a religious community. Known as the Kane Street Synagogue, or Congregation Baith Israel Anshei Emes, the institution they founded is still in operation in Cobble Hill. The records from that first
title: COBBLE HILL: THE WORDS; From the Distant Past, Tales of Cantors and Corpses

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 36-01 35th Avenue, at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. One of the largest collections of moving-image artifacts. Screenings this weekend: Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers'' (1956), directed by Don Siegel; at 4 p.m., ''Them!'' (1954), directed by Gordon Douglas.
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Erin Creeve Dockery, a daughter of Anne and John P. Dockery of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Martin Cormac MacDermott, the son of Kathleen MacDermott of Glenamaddy, Ireland, and the late Dermot MacDermott. The Rev. Andrew Johnson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the chapel at Clongowes Wood College, a boarding school in
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Erin Dockery, Cormac MacDermott

body: An article on Saturday about the death of a man set on fire inside a Brooklyn apartment misidentified the neighborhood where the crime occurred. It was Boerum Hill, not Cobble Hill.
title: Corrections

body: A man died yesterday after he was doused with a flammable liquid and set on fire inside a Brooklyn apartment, the authorities said. Five people were injured in the blaze. The fire started shortly after 3 a.m. in a seventh-floor apartment at 185 Nevins Street in the Wyckoff Gardens housing complex in Cobble Hill. A man poured a flammable liquid on
title: Man Dies After Being Set Ablaze in Brooklyn

body: David Sandoval, who cleans the floors of the Met Foods Supermarket in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, walks in through the front door most evenings around 8:30. But when the gates come down an hour later, he says, the door is locked, and he is unable to leave until the manager comes in the next morning. Zeferino Arenas Abundez, who scrubs and waxes floors
title: Workers Say Late Shifts Often Mean Locked Exits

body: Pamela Sherwood Luchansky and Chester Frank Kaplan were married last evening at the River Cafe in Brooklyn. Justice Michael A. Corriero of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated. Ms. Luchansky, 56, is keeping her name. She was an owner of the Brooklyn Bagel Company, a maker of frozen bagels, and of the Brooklyn Pie Company, which distributed
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Pamela Luchansky, Chester Kaplan

body: THERE is a reason that Kenneth Adams is called Mr. Brooklyn, though he demurs that this honorific is inappropriate. ''I'm more comfortable if I'm called 'the Other Mr. Brooklyn,''' says Mr. Adams, the hyperkinetic president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. He pipes up that the real Mr. Brooklyn is Marty Markowitz, the borough president. ''He's
title: PUBLIC LIVES; If Brooklyn's Your Borough, Then He's Your Guy

body: Laura Bush and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stood shoulder to shoulder yesterday in an appearance that may well dispel any lingering doubt as to the mayor's feelings about the president, or of the mayor's own political identity. Mr. Bloomberg -- a Democrat who turned Republican to run for mayor -- came to the first lady's aid as she tried to calm a
title: On Iraq War, Bloomberg Lends Support To First Lady

body: EVER since Manhattan became Manhattan, it seems, the island has been viewed as a roost for the rich. In the mid-19th century, Walt Whitman compared Manhattan with Brooklyn, then a suburb of New York City: ''Men of moderate means may find homes at a moderate rent, whereas in New York City there is no median between a palatial mansion and a
title: The Nation: Moving Up or Out; It's Very Fancy on Old Delancey Street, You Know

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites HISPANIC SOCIETY OF AMERICA, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. Tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., a free Centennial Festival in celebration of Spanish and Latin American history and culture, with music and dance performances, a treasure hunt and a gallery talk. Information: (212) 926-2234.
title: SPARE TIMES

body: In 1995, when Vera Jeffery started working at Treasures Thrift Emporium on Smith Street, the thoroughfare was a threadbare strip little known beyond Cobble Hill and Boerum Hill, the two Brooklyn neighborhoods it separated. Ms. Jeffery, who lives in the nearby Gowanus Houses, recalls cracked sidewalks, unsavory characters and empty storefronts. Ms.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL/BOERUM HILL; Even an Outpost of Funkiness Can't Survive on a Funky Street

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Tomorrow from 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., 31st Astronomy Day, when participants can observe sunspots and read a star map. title: SPARE TIMES

body: After rivers of debate and publicity over Mel Gibson's ''Passion of the Christ,'' Hollywood and Holy Week are meeting in a moment of high Christian drama. The movie has become enmeshed with the most solemn Christian religious days of the year -- Palm Sunday, Holy Thursday, Good Friday today and Easter Sunday -- when Jesus' final days and
title: A Season Of Faith And a Film; Gibson's Movie Goes to Church

body: FOLLEK--Ruth, 89, of New York, New York on April 5, 2004. Survived by son Robert and daughter-in-law Stacy Feldman. Predeceased by husband Jack. Ruth loved the theatre, the opera, Scrabble and the Times. Her family and many friends will miss her. At her request, there will be no service. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the Cobble Hill
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FOLLEK, RUTH

body: Like Wall Street and Delancey Street, Atlantic Avenue is one of those New York thoroughfares whose names conjure up distinctive worlds, in its case an incongruous mix of a Middle Eastern bazaar where you can actually buy frankincense and myrrh and a row of Victorian antique shops. A livelier Atlantic Avenue has been shaking off that stereotype for
title: Brooklyn's Mile-Long Makeover; Atlantic Avenue Is at the Heart of Plans for a Pier, Arena and Park

body: WHEN Andrea Burns and Peter Flynn were expecting their first child last year, they considered a two-bedroom Midtown apartment that a relative was giving up and looked in their Greenwich Village neighborhood, where they wanted to stay. Their choices seemed to come down to a fifth-floor walkup in a neighborhood they did not like (with no washing
title: TURF; Packing Comfort Into a Pod

body: It takes fire engines 30 seconds longer on average to respond to medical emergencies in the six New York City neighborhoods where engine companies were closed last spring, opponents of the closings said yesterday. Using response time data provided by the Fire Department, State Assemblyman Jeffrey Klein said the increase had dangerous implications
title: Firehouse Closings Slowed Response Times, Opponents Say

body: AS though her convoluted deal of nine years ago did not already constitute a broker's symphony -- juggling all interested parties so that three apartments on the same floor of a Park Avenue co-op building could be sold and converted into one -- Suzanne Sealy has written a coda. In a market of constricted inventory, Ms. Sealy of the William B. May
title: Supply Varies, Demand Doesn't

author: Zachary Pincus-Roth writes about theater for Variety.
body: YOUNG playwrights dream of having a runaway success like ''Proof.'' David Auburn's drama ran for 917 performances at the Walter Kerr Theater before closing on Jan. 5, 2003, making it the longest-running Broadway play in two decades. ''Proof,'' which originally opened Off Broadway in 2000 at the Manhattan Theater Club and then transferred to
title: THEATER; David Auburn's Burden Of 'Proof'

body: For some, South Brooklyn will always be South Brooklyn, although it is, in fact, in northern Brooklyn, and is also referred to, alternatively, as Carroll Gardens, Red Hook, Boerum Hill and the Columbia Waterfront District. But another name for the area has emerged, in the form of a well-appointed Web site and a series of sleek brochures: BoCoCa.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; The Newest Entry In Neighborhood Scrabble

body: This is not the first time that Carmen Fariña has been called upon as a troubleshooter. Three years ago, she was enlisted to turn around District 15 in Brooklyn, after the previous superintendent was forced out over huge budget overruns and complaints from parents about his management style. Now, Ms. Fariña, a Brooklyn native and longtime city
title: A Troubleshooter With a Passion for Schools

author: Phillip Lopate is the author, most recently, of ''Waterfront: A Journey Around Manhattan,'' published last month by Crown, from which this essay is adapted.
body: WHEN John Waldman, an ichthyologist with the Hudson River Foundation, invited me to join him and several others on an expedition to the deserted North and South Brother Islands, in the vicinity of Hell Gate, I leapt at the chance, not sure quite what to expect. John is a good-looking man in his 40's with silky, prematurely silvered hair, and I had
title: Beached Males

body: Manhattan GREENWICH VILLAGE $605,000 55 East Ninth Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. co-op in a post-World War II building; dining room, renovated kitchen and bath, central air-conditioning, balcony; laundry facilities in building; maintenance $964, 50% tax-deductible; listed at $615,000, 8 weeks on market (broker: Bellmarc Realty) GRAMERCY

body: For years, at thousands of New York City intersections, well-worn push buttons have offered harried walkers a rare promise of control over their pedestrian lives. The signs mounted above explained their purpose: To Cross Street Push Button Wait for Walk Signal Dept. of Transportation Millions of dutiful city residents and tourists have pushed them
title: For Exercise in New York Futility, Push Button

author: Helene Stapinski's newest memoir, ''Baby Plays Around: A Love Affair With Music,'' was published last month by Villard.
body: IT was a Thursday afternoon, and Sam Stillman was starting the trek back to Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. From the stone-arch doorway of Elisabeth Irwin High School, the West Village private school where Sam, 16, is a sophomore, he headed to the F train, book bag slung across his chest, just another teenager headed home. The stares began when he got off
title: Preppy Punks

author: Thomas Boyle, a professor of English at Brooklyn College, is the author of several crime novels set in Brooklyn.
body: OUT here in Brooklyn, we hear that New Jersey's Nets are coming. This could be great news, but at the same time it brings back the bitter memory of the nasty departure of our baseball Dodgers in 1957. And just over a week ago, Gage & Tollner, our oldest restaurant and most charming culinary relic of the dear departed 19th century (sorry about that,
title: CITY LORE; Put Down That Violin. Now.

body: To the Editor: Re: ''You Can Buy a Cellphone, but What Happened to Quaint?'' (Feb. 8): I have lived in or near Brooklyn Heights for 26 years, and I never once set foot in Summa Gallery on Montague Street, but I was in the MAC store the first week it opened. I am also grateful for the recent arrival of Nine West and Aerosoles; previously, you had to
title: Changes in Neighborhood Need Not Harm Character

body: Call it the Valentine's Day massacre. Lutèce and Gage & Tollner, two historic restaurants that for decades had attained almost the status of civic institutions, will shut their doors on the same day, tomorrow. Another, La Côte Basque, will follow early next month. Hands wring. Diners mourn. The New is cursed. Doom is inferred. Darkness descends.
title: Eat and Be Merry; Tomorrow 2 Classics Die

body: FOR Donald Pandina, the blow came a year ago. It was time to renegotiate the lease on Summa Gallery, an art and framing store he had owned with a partner in Brooklyn Heights for 35 years, the last 27 of them at 152 Montague Street. He thought he had reached an oral agreement with his landlord over the new lease. ''But then one day I got a phone
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; You Can Buy a Cellphone, But What Happened to Quaint?

body: The boxy white garbage truck lumbered along West 96th Street in Manhattan yesterday and stopped just short of four bins full of trash. Then the truck, a front-loader with two heavy steel prongs jutting out like the horns of a charging bull, nosed forward to lock onto one bin as a city sanitation worker waved the vehicle forward like a nervous
title: Crews Find Daily Perils in Picking Up the Trash

body: Sometimes it is four or five flights that stand between them and the sunshine. Sometimes it is only 12 stairs -- a physical barrier so daunting that it has virtually marooned many aged or ailing New Yorkers in apartments they cannot afford to give up, trapped high above the teeming street life they once enjoyed and took for granted. Were it not for
title: Stuck in a Walk-Up, Only Steps Away From Life

body: The Bloomberg administration, after a two-year review of the city's property tax laws, has delayed a broad legislative push to overhaul New York City's tax assessment system after concluding such changes would be politically impossible in Albany now. The city Finance Department is still moving ahead with internal changes in how it supervises its
title: City Backs Off Overhaul Effort On Assessments

body: Brooklyn nurses its grudge against Manhattan with all the subtlety of King Kong, a Red Sox fan or Gerald R. Ford. So this may come as perverse consolation, but slowly, quietly and over the course of decades, the borough has created something -- or, rather, a conspicuous nothing -- that elevates it among the ranks of the country's real, independent
title: Plugging a Hole in Brooklyn's Heart; A Web of Urban Challenges to Rival Dallas or Los Angeles

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.
